because a band could not produce a million CDs without them, but a band can with a smaller comparative budget make an MP3, so a million MP3s

children.author: artilleus
children.comment: Everything they did has become cheaper, easier to coordinate with fewer people, and the physical production part was really important
Physical production is only a small part of what record labels did. If you wanted to do everything ELSE they did by yourself then you could
Which is harder/more expensive than getting a record label contract how?
A band without access to a data hosting site is at a disadvantage now.
It was only negligible for a handful of actors; a band without access to a CD factory was at a disadvantage that doesn't exist anymore
Yes, but the production cost was a negligible part of the end price ANYWAY. Remove that production cost, how much does the consumer save?
No inventory investment, no need for large returns to scale by owning the entire production chain. Infinite copies at no extra cost

children.author: artilleus
children.comment: Not true.  You could not literally from anywhere take one CD and make it a million at no extra cost.  That is what I'm talking about.
CDs were cheap to make. The end cost for the consumer was only negligibly impacted by the cost of producing the CD. Little has changed.
But the structure does need to adjust to account for the fact that a copy of an MP3 is free to make in a way CDs never were.

children.author: artilleus
children.comment: used to be CDs, which had finite marginal costs, as opposed to MP3s which really don't. The whole supply chain isn't falling away

That has always been true as well, just replace YouTube with the town bar. I'm addressing the actual copy of the song that is sold, AKA

children.author: IMadeAnAccountJustToWriteThis
children.comment: No, but they never DID, for recorded art. The price involved ALWAYS represented compensation for the artist, and the work involved in
But one copy of a digital good has effectively the same cost as an infinite number, so the normal laws of supply and demand don't apply.
Only in the sense that consumers prefer looking in one place for everything they want. Kill the store and you make products harder to find.
True, but market forces after production is finished effectively work in favor of a price-discriminating monopoly structure.
They can't consume for free if there's nothing to consume. Producers need money to produce.
The ability to infinitely copy MP3/4s at no cost has effectively shifted the supply curve far enough out that people can consume for free.
